resources.string: Use emergency services if you require \n immediate help and non-emergency services \n if you require non-immediate help.
Use these services in your location if you \n require immediate help.
Use these services in your location if you \n require %1$s
Use these services in your location if you \n require non-immediate help.
Create a profile so you can start saving \n numbers from the ‘Home’ and ‘Search’ \n directory pages.
Access the save number option under icon \n on the ‘Home’ and ‘Search’ directory pages.

By saving this profile you agree to 911+’s
Privacy Policy.
EMERGENCY AND NON-EMERGENCY SERVICE \n CONTACTS FOR WHEREVER YOU GO!
Examples of emergency situations could be:

• An event that involves an immediate threat to 
person or property: screams, attacks, gunshots, 
fire, car accident with injuries or any other 
medical emergency.
• A substantive, in-progress crime. This includes \nfights, break and enters (if there is a suspect on \nscene) or a report of an impaired driver.
• A serious crime that has just occurred (e.g., \nsexual assault or robbery).
• A suspicious circumstance that may indicate \nan immediate criminal act (e.g., robber, vandal).
Definitions and examples obtained from E-Comm Emergency \n Communications for British Columbia Incorporated.
• Reporting a crime with no suspect (e.g., theft \nof licence plate).
• Reporting a crime with suspect, but suspect is \nnot on the scene (e.g.,fraud).
• Reporting a serious crime with suspect, but \nwith a lengthy delay (e.g., assault that occurred \nlast night at a bar).
• Non-emergency incidents in progress \n(e.g., noisy party, drug use).
• Ongoing crime issues or crimes that are not in \nprogress (e.g., graffiti or ongoing drug dealing \nwith no suspect on scene).
• A suspicious circumstance that may indicate \nan ongoing criminal activity (e.g., illegal drug \noperation).
